org.apache.hawq.pxf.plugins.hbase

Class HBaseFilterBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.hawq.pxf.plugins.hbase.HBaseFilterBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    FilterParser.FilterBuilder

    public class HBaseFilterBuilder
extends java.lang.Object
implements FilterParser.FilterBuilder
    This is the implementation of FilterParser.FilterBuilder for HBase.

    The class uses the filter parser code to build a filter object, either simple (single Filter class) or a compound (FilterList) for HBaseAccessor to use for its scan.

    This is done before the scan starts. It is not a scan time operation.

    HBase row key column is a special case. If the user defined row key column as TEXT and used <,>,<=,>=,= operators the startkey (>/>=) and the endkey (</<=) are stored in addition to the created filter. This is an addition on top of regular filters and does not replace any logic in HBase filter objects.

      • startKey

        public byte[] startKey()
        Returns the startKey for scanning the HBase table. If the user specified a > / >= operation on a textual row key column, this value will be returned. Otherwise, the start of table.
        Returns:
        start key for scanning HBase table

      • endKey

        public byte[] endKey()
        Returns the endKey for scanning the HBase table. If the user specified a < / <= operation on a textual row key column, this value will be returned. Otherwise, the end of table.
        Returns:
        end key for scanning HBase table

      • build

        public java.lang.Object build(FilterParser.Operation opId,
                              java.lang.Object leftOperand,
                              java.lang.Object rightOperand)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Builds a filter from the input operands and operation. Two kinds of operations are handled:
        1. Simple operation between FilterParser.Constant and FilterParser.ColumnIndex. Supported operations are <, >, <=, <=, >=, =, !=.
        2. Compound operations between Filter objects. The only supported operation is AND.

        This function is called by FilterParser, each time the parser comes across an operator.

        Specified by:
        build in interface FilterParser.FilterBuilder
        Parameters:
        opId - the parse operation to perform
        leftOperand - the left operand
        rightOperand - the right operand
        Returns:
        the built filter
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if building the filter failed
